headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Bolsonaro Refuses to Concede; Manhunt in New Jersey; Kentucky School District Cancels Classes; Powerball Grows to $1.2 billion; New Study on Excessive Drinking; NYC Employers Must Reveal Salaries in Job Listings; The Science Behind Cheating. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: BIANCA NOBILO, CNN ANCHOR CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: It's tacit approval of what the protesters are doing.And as what Max was saying, some of the language so close to what we heard from former President Donald Trump. For example, his son, Bolsonaro's son, said they're expecting the greatest election fraud in their history. And that was a few days ago.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: NOBILO
utterances.sentences: So you can see the parallels in the rhetoric there.And, of course, as we often see with strong men leaders, and those that have qualities of them, there is this us and them populist narrative, which Bolsonaro has been perpetuating through all of this.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Well, that's the thing -

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes, the reason this matters -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Hang on. I just want to ask, that's a thing of violence. The violence here, that's the issue because we saw what happened at the Capitol on January 6th. When you look at the violence in the streets, you're right, it is tacit and it does mimic what happened here in the United States. It is important for officials, whether it's here in the United States or wherever, to concede elections. That's the important stuff (ph).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, and that's why it matters that he's, as Max noted, you know, he's not conceding, he's not contesting it -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: By that silence matters because, as what you just saw there, that video, those are Bolsonaro's own supporters protesting by blocking the roads. And it's causing so many issues.

utterances.speaker: NOBILO
utterances.sentences: And the other element of that, Kaitlan, is the fact that it is tradition in Brazilian politics, as it is in most democracies, for the person who's unsuccessful in the election to call the winner and officially concede. So that is actually part of the peaceful transfer of power. And that notably has not happened.

utterances.speaker: MAX FOSTER, CNN ANCHOR AND CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: And he has called for his protesters not to be violent.  He's saying that's something of the left. But, as you're saying, you know, those scenes are playing out.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.You know, just to bring this home, I mean they call him the Trump - many call him the Trump of the tropics, right, for the reason that you noted, Bianca. But just take it home to the people. The Brazilian people are suffering. They have been suffering for so many years under Bolsonaro's, you know, power. And the inflation is out of control. There is such extensive poverty. So, this matters deeply for Brazilians what happens and if Lula coming back into power can actually turn things around, as he's promised.

utterances.speaker: FOSTER
utterances.sentences: Well, the chance for him is this, you know, completely disunited country -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: FOSTER
utterances.sentences: And two very clear sides to the debate. And it's left and it's right. And Lula's somehow got to bring -- unite people. And that's going to be a huge challenge.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: NOBILO
utterances.sentences: I think when you have an election result where the difference between the two main parties is only 1.8 percent and they are on completely opposite ends of the political spectrum -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: NOBILO
utterances.sentences: It's, obviously, going to deepen and stir division.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Fair point.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you both. I appreciate it. Max and Bianca.It's interesting. I think one of these leaders take cues from each other, right? Obviously, a lot of them are taking cues from what happened here in the United States and President Trump.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, many transitions happening around the world we're having -- watching what's happening in Israel as well very closely.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.There is a manhunt in Newark, New Jersey, that we need to get to now for a suspect who shot two police officers who were trying to arrest him.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Also, what you need to know before having that second drink to help you unwind maybe in the evening after work. We've got new details.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy. Wow.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, bad for us.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to CNN THIS MORNING. We're so glad you're with us this morning.It is the bottom of the hour. Time for more news. Let's get to the domestic beat. Our colleague, Brynn Gingras, is here. Good morning, Brynn.

utterances.speaker: BRYNN GINGRAS, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, hey, guys, good morning.A suspect remains at large after two New Jersey police officers were shot attempting to make an arrest. This happened in Newark last night. Authorities searched an apartment building where they thought Kendall Howard was hiding but police couldn't find him. One of the officers was shot in the leg, the other was shot in the shoulder. The bullet grazing his neck. Both are in stable condition. In Kentucky, at least one school district outside Lexington is canceling classes for a week, writing on Facebook this, the Powell County Schools will be closed due to illness through the evening of November 8th. We'll resume school after Election Day, the morning of November 9th. And it could be a billion-dollar night. So, get your tickets. The Powerball jackpot has climbed to $1.2 billion after no one matched the winning numbers in Monday night's drawing. And, guys, I would ask you, are you going to quit your jobs if you win?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GINGRAS
utterances.sentences: But that's not an option.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We just started yesterday.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well (ph) -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, if I don't show up on Thursday, you'll know why. It's because I left at 9

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You mean - you mean we left.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You would miss us.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I would share.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You would miss us, Kaitlan.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I would come by as a guest.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Come on.

utterances.speaker: GINGRAS
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I'd come by as Dr. Tara. I'd stop in and say hi.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Brynn.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Brynn. Really appreciate that.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Brynn.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK, a glass of wine or a beer after work is a pretty common way for people to unwind. A new study just published, though, might make you think twice about pouring yourself that second drink.Joining us now, CNN medical correspondent Dr. Tara Narula.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Good morning.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You have said -DR. TARA NARULA, CNN MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wait, wait, wait, wait, what?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wait, what?

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: This is not what you want to hear, right?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Do you know how stressful people's lives are now?

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What's the deal? NARULASo, what we know is that excess alcohol use is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. In fact, it is a leading, preventable cause of premature death and death rates for alcohol- attributable causes have been going up for the past decade. So, researchers here looked at alcohol consumption from 2015 to 2019 in U.S. adults and they found that one in eight deaths in those 20 to 64 were attributable to alcohol, excessive alcohol, OK. One in five deaths in those 20 to 49 were also attributable to excessive alcohol consumption. And it was higher in men than women. It varied across states. So highest in New Mexico, lowest in Mississippi. In general, the southeast had lower rates and the west, upper Midwest, New England higher rates.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: And when we're talking about what are these causes. So, we're talking about poisoning, motor vehicle accidents. By poisoning we mean substance used with alcohol. Motor vehicle accidents and alcohol related liver disease.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: So -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Where's it higher? Well, I'm sorry. Where was it higher again?

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: So it's higher in the west, the upper Midwest and New England. The southeast had lower rates.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: So what - you're talking about excessive use.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: What is - what is that defined by? What's the acceptable use?

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Right. And so there's a lot of debate about, you know, is it safe to drink at all? And, really, there's not a lot of great what we call randomized controlled trials on this topic. But what we generally say is that if you drink moderately, that that's technically for many considered safe. And by moderate let's define that. So we're talking about, at most, one glass a day for women, two glasses a day for men. And when we're talking about the types, it's about 12 ounces of beer, 5 ounces of wine, 1.5 ounces of hard liquor.Now, there has been some association with moderate drinking and lower risk of cardiovascular disease. On the other hand, you have to weigh that with the cancer risk. We know that there's increased risk of cancer. So, there is some debate there. We definitely don't tell people to start drinking if they're not drinking. But if you keep it at that moderate level it may be OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That's just interesting because we have just such a natural acceptance of alcohol in our society and our relationship to it.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And maybe we need to rethink that. We started, you know, when marijuana became more acceptable and more main stream and it seems like the benefits of maybe moderate marijuana use may be better than moderate alcohol use. I think that we need to start thinking about that.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: We should be mindful how we use alcohol.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We need to be mindful. Absolutely.Thank you, Doctor Narula. We appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Doctor.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Straight ahead, Charles Barkley calling Brooklyn Nets star Kyrie Irving, I'm quoting him here, an idiot. And he has some choice words for the NBA as well.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: A Charles Barkley quote is getting some attention?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I'm shocked.If you ever wondered how much your colleagues are getting paid if you live in New York City, like the three of us, you might be able to find out very soon.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'm looking at you two. I'm looking at you two.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thank you. That's --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Or you three, I should say, Doctor.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's really great seeing you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Do you ever wonder - do you ever wonder just how much your best friend makes? HARLOW

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Really? Really?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I feel like my friends are pretty open to talk about what they make.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Why'd you look at me?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, that's so -- I did not look - who you looking at?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: A new law in New York may let you in on that secret. It requires employers to post salary ranges for job listings. So, here's how - this - how one New York City council member who sponsored the bill describes it. Listen to this.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JUSTIN BRANNAN, NEW YORK CITY COUNCIL MEMBER
utterances.sentences: The fact that you'd apply for a job not knowing what the salary range is, is just insane. It's critical to both our economy and to gender and racial justice.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, some companies have already started updating their listings in New York City and beyond really.So, joining me now, CNN business and politics correspondent Vanessa Yurkevich. Good morning to you.

utterances.speaker: VANESSA YURKEVICH, CNN BUSINESS AND POLITICS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Good morning.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much for that.Listen, I guess, really, what is the point? Is it equity? Is it -- what's the point?

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. Equity, trying to get women on par with men in terms of salaries. This law says that if you are a company with four or more employees and one of them works in New York City, you must post salary ranges for any job that you're looking to fill in New York City. It exempts temp firms.But the key here is that if you do not post a salary, companies can be fined $250,000. So this is really trying to get companies to do good due diligence and really explaining to people what this job is worth.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It - it -- you said it applies to companies with one - or with four or more employees. But I imagine larger companies will be able to do this a lot faster than smaller companies will be able to. Is there a disparity there?

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Potentially it's -- for larger companies they may be able to auto generate this really quickly in their ads online. But for a smaller company who maybe has a flyer that they're posting in the neighborhood, they still have to post that salary range but it may be harder for them to sort of get on board with this.But it's important to note that there is a wide range of salaries that are being offered right now. Big -- sort of what they're calling good faith salaries that they have to abide by.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I have so many questions for you, but go - (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: OK. Go ahead. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Hello.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Hi.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This matters is because -

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Women, minorities -

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Often are paid less than their white male counterparts or their male counterparts. This is just a reality. It just still persists.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Eighty-three cents to the dollar.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I remember when Marc Benioff at Salesforce went in like five, six years ago, he was alerted at the company, women are making less. He went in. They did a huge audit of the whole company. And he came to the press. I sat down with him. He's like, we were wrong. I was wrong. We are fixing this.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But unless you do that -

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You end up with this.This is why it matters. And I love that Kaitlan said she talks to her friends about what they make. Women need to do that more and more and more and more.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: A lot of people don't, though.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: A lot of people don't. And this will really try to put men, women, and especially women of color who are known to make less - HARLOW

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Than all of the above sort of to just put it on paper, to put it on paper for people and hopefully give people a better sense of what they're worth and what their colleagues are worth.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Everything you said is true. OK. But not everybody in the same job performance the same.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, it is nuanced here. You know, should a -- someone who is just an average player -- I'm just using - you know, be paid as much as LeBron James or -

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Well, that's why you have this range.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, you understand what I'm saying?

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: There's a huge range.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, it is - there is nuance. And, yes, typically women and people of color get paid less than white men, but not everybody is a great performer, and your salary - I think in some ways your salary needs to reflect that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's a good point.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Let's just - let's just put up some of the current job.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: This is (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Yes. So we did a little job search -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. OK.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: But, you know, it's a - it's a big range.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This is what bonuses are for. Big bonuses.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Yes. This doesn't include bonus.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) not everybody gets a bonus. So, not everybody is in that position.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right No, absolutely - absolutely not. A lot of -- I was talking about the NBA players.Well, I don't get a bonus. I was talking about the NBA players.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Not any more.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This was -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: To be continued.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This was fascinating, Vanessa. Thank you very, very much.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK, so, pro-sports --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Speaking of, yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Speaking of the NBA. Players pro-sports have seen quite a few incidents of cheating in recent years. Our Dr. Sanjay Gupta joins us to discuss, why do we cheat?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. What, cheating in sports?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I didn't know people do that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm not sure if he'll be able to answer that.Plus, voters in Arizona are feeling intimidated, they say, by armed patrols that are happening at ballot boxes, like the one you see here. We have a report on the right-wing group that is behind what you're seeing. That's up next.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, that should not be allowed to happen. Look at that. You -- anyone would be intimidated.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) feel like a regular person can go vote. It looks crazy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Of course. Of course it does.(COMMERCIAL BREAK) (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We got weights in fish. Get the (EXPLETIVE DELETED) out of here! Get the (EXPLETIVE DELETED) out of here!(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I remember that, Kaitlan. (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Everybody remembers that moment, of course. It was the last time you saw a fishing tournament go viral, except for the one that I was in at nine years old.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wait.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: For real?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Here - yes, I have a picture. I'll bring it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, gosh.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: My fish was like two pounds. No weights inside of it.Anyway, a pair of competitive fishermen were disqualified from an Ohio tournament recently when organizers found that they had stuffed their fish with these lead weights.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The alleged cheating has also rocked the world of chess. This is something I was personally fascinated by. The American Grand Master, Hans Niemann, filed a defamation lawsuit against the world champion, accusing him of colluding with others to try to ruin his career.And, of course, if -- we cannot forget the Houston Astros, who are currently duking it out with the Phillies in the World Series, as they did last night, if you stayed up late. In 2017 they were caught using an elaborate scheme involving video cameras to steal the opposing team's signs. By the way, the won the World Series that year. I was there because they played the Nats.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: They had the -- remember the drum thing. Like, they would give away signals with the drum cry. It's all kinds of stuff. I thought we were talking about cheating in relationships, but here we are.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, that - that could be a factor in this, but -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Sanjay says there's a second week topic.DR. SANJAY GUPTA, CNN CHIEF MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: That's a second week segment.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Hello, Dr. Gupta. Who are you this morning?

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Good. COLLINS

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: This plays into so much what's happening in our politics right now.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I think - I think there is probably some relationships here in all these sectors of society. But when it comes to competitive sports, so many of them are won by increments, small little increments. So, to win, you have to cheat a little bit to get that small increment. Didn't really cheat even though it gave you enough to win in a very competitive sport.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Doping, et cetera.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: So -- doping. So we're seeing that a lot in, again, many sectors of society.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Do - OK. So, last night I played the matching game with Luca, who's four, you know, where you flip over the cards and match.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Did he - did he win?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And then -- he won. But he won fair and square. And I was like, Luca, you can just go again. And he goes, no, mom, that's cheating. And I was like, thank you, Luca.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: So you set up  a -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK, so kids don't, by habit or nature, know to cheat. They learn to cheat. Then we learn to cheat. But who is more likely to cheat and why?

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Well, so, there have been studies on this and they've - and the conclusion to the study, I'll give you the headline first, is that if the proper and certain behavioral cues are there, just about everyone will cheat. Just about everyone. Gender, age, doesn't matter. There are certain really subtle behavioral cues that make it much more likely to happen.A couple of them, you think no one's watching. That's - that's sort of the big one. And, again, no surprise there. Dim or messy environments. So, if you think there's a little chaotic environment, you're going to be more likely to cheat in those sorts of environments.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Dim, you mean lighting?

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, lighting.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Oh.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Just some - simply as - simple as lighting.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Casino?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Fishing.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: If you believe that there's an abundance of resources, there's enough to go around, it's not really going to matter if it's a money thing, for example. If you are tired, you are more likely to not have enough willpower to not cheat. So, they're doing all these standardized tests, for example, on Saturday mornings, all these high school kids are super tired at that point, more likely to cheat as a result.And also people who are in position of power. You know, people who stand like this, you know, positions of power. You find that --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Don's looking at --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: No, I'm - I'm not - I'm look at (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Up next we have a CNN exclusive. This is really, really chilling. A 911 call from a girl who was trapped inside the classroom with the Uvalde school shooter as the law enforcement was waiting outside for 40 minutes before they acted. Her mother is going to join us ahead to tell us what it's like to listen to her daughter call 911.
